newsitem.title: USA: Mass. fines Goldman Sachs, ex-state official.
newsitem.headline: Mass. fines Goldman Sachs, ex-state official.

text.p: Massachusetts State Ethics Commission on Thursday fined underwriter Goldman, Sachs & Co $3,500 for providing illegal gifts to two former state officials -- a deputy state treasurer and the head of the state's Health and Education Facilities Authority (HEFA).

Goldman, Sachs was the lead underwriter for approximately 25 percent of the $6.4 billion in bonds issued by HEFA between 1989 and 1995 and earned several million dollars in commissions from the deals, the ethics agency noted in its deposition.

Goldman, Sachs admitted it violated state laws when in March 1992 its vice president Daniel McCarthy provided then deputy state treasurer Steven Kaseta with tickets to a show and dinner in Boston and again wined and dined him in New York City.
The underwriter also admitted to providing then HEFA executive director Edward Murphy to dinners and a show in Boston, New York, and Phoenix, Ariz.

State law prohibits anyone from giving directly or indirectly anything of substantial value in exhcnge for an official act performed. Substantial value is considered anything worth $50 or more. Both men accepted gifts worth at least $500.
The ethics commission, in additon to fining Goldman Sachs $3,500, also fined former deputy treasurer Kaseta $1,500 and issued a public enforcement letter to Murphy.
